articles.headline: Reading This While Walking? In Honolulu, It Could Cost You
articles.snippet: The city has passed a law designed to protect pedestrians staring at their smartphones from themselves. But critics say engineering and redesigning streets would be more effective.
articles.abstract: The city has passed a law designed to protect pedestrians staring at their smartphones from themselves. But critics say engineering and redesigning streets would be more effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: You see them everywhere: people walking with their eyes glued to their mobile phone screens on busy streets. But walking and texting can be dangerous — and cities in the United States and Europe have begun to do something about it.

articles.headline: Cutting Taxes Is Hard. Trump Is Making It Harder.
articles.snippet: Republicans are worried that President Trump’s musings could doom their best chance for a sweeping tax rewrite.
articles.abstract: Republicans are worried that President Trump’s musings could doom their best chance for a sweeping tax rewrite.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that he would oppose any effort to reduce the amount of pretax income that American workers can save in 401(k) retirement accounts, effectively killing an idea that Republicans were mulling as a way to help pay for a $1.5 trillion tax cut.

articles.headline: Russia’s Favored Outlet Is an Online News Giant. YouTube Helped.
articles.snippet: RT was early to embrace the video site. Now that relationship is drawing scrutiny as investigators look into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.
articles.abstract: RT was early to embrace the video site. Now that relationship is drawing scrutiny as investigators look into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the state-backed Russian news channel RT became the first news organization to surpass one billion views on YouTube in 2013, it marked the achievement with a retrospective of its most popular videos and a special guest — one of the Google-owned site’s senior executives.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: In the Saudi Desert, World’s Business Leaders Follow the Money
articles.snippet: The kingdom is embarking on a big experiment as it diversifies its oil-based economy, and executives looking for investment are making their pitches.
articles.abstract: The kingdom is embarking on a big experiment as it diversifies its oil-based economy, and executives looking for investment are making their pitches.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Private jets ferrying business titans from all over the globe began landing Monday in this sand-swept Saudi capital.

articles.headline: End of Apartheid in South Africa? Not in Economic Terms
articles.snippet: Political liberation has yet to translate into material gains for blacks. As one woman said, “I’ve gone from a shack to a shack.”
articles.abstract: Political liberation has yet to translate into material gains for blacks. As one woman said, “I’ve gone from a shack to a shack.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CROSSROADS, South Africa — The end of apartheid was supposed to be a beginning.

articles.headline: Across Myanmar, Denial of Ethnic Cleansing and Loathing of Rohingya
articles.snippet: Claims that atrocities were staged, along with stark hate speech against Rohingya Muslims, are blaring out from social media and official statements.
articles.abstract: Claims that atrocities were staged, along with stark hate speech against Rohingya Muslims, are blaring out from social media and official statements.
articles.lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — The Buddhist abbot tucked his legs under his robes and began to explain.

articles.headline: Black Executives Join Forces, Forming a PAC to Back Them Up
articles.snippet: Once an informal network, a group of friends and associates is organizing a united political push on issues like education, employment and voting rights.
articles.abstract: Once an informal network, a group of friends and associates is organizing a united political push on issues like education, employment and voting rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dozens of black executives and their spouses joined Senators Cory Booker and Kamala Harris, as well as Eric H. Holder Jr., the former attorney general, for a private dinner in July in Bridgehampton, N.Y. Over kale salad and sea bass on the grounds of a hotel, the executives sought advice about their intermittent fund-raising efforts to address political and social issues, and for the candidates who support those causes.

articles.headline: China Enshrines ‘Xi Jinping Thought.’ What Does That Mean?
articles.snippet: The Communist Party has added the president’s name and ideas to its constitution. Here is what that means.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party has added the president’s name and ideas to its constitution. Here is what that means.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese Communist Party wrote Xi Jinping’s name and ideas into its constitution on Tuesday, elevating him at the end of his first five-year term to the same exalted status as the nation’s founding father, Mao Zedong.

articles.headline: Expelling Immigrant Workers May Also Send Away the Work They Do
articles.snippet: American-born workers probably won’t benefit from a job bonanza if laborers who are in the United States illegally, especially farmworkers, are deported, most research has shown.
articles.abstract: American-born workers probably won’t benefit from a job bonanza if laborers who are in the United States illegally, especially farmworkers, are deported, most research has shown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few American industries are as invested in the decades-long political battle over immigration as agriculture. Paying low wages for backbreaking work, growers large and small have historically relied on immigrants from south of the Rio Grande. These days, over one-quarter of the farmhands in the United States are immigrants working here illegally.
